The best game ever. Would recommend Portal 2, tho.
The most classic puzzle game of all time

A really thrilling game especially the parts after the last level where it feels like a horror Slenderman-esque game where you're expecting a jump scare every time. Best part about the game was that it was challenging and short at the same time. Love the whole portal mechanic which was ahead of it's time.

Should you play this game? Should you give Valve your money? Should you experience one of the best games in human history. Why yes, yes you should.
This game is an accepted classic, and for good reason. If you bring yourself back into the time-span of when this game came out, you can start to see just how revolutionary it truly was, and is. It pioneered the modern use of a portal system (which many games now apply for a plethora of uses - the new Ratchet and Clank is a good modern example) and how to bring a story to life in a minimalistic way. The story itself is pretty minimal, but very impactful, and yet only told through voice-lines and simple puzzle gameplay. So many games now try to replicate Portal in terms of puzzles, and that's just because of how affective it was and how well the consumers responded to it. Racking your brain to solve what I like to call an "active puzzle" (where you solve puzzles in real time, usually in 3D environments for extra immersion - little nightmares being a good example) is extremely satisfying, especially when you get some awesome story to really juice it up. Finding hidden Easter eggs is very fun and adds to the overall experience of being in Aperture. This game forever cemented Aperture right up front with the likes of Black Mesa, and will forever be within our hearts. Valve deserves all the money this game costs and then some, along with our undying support for sticking with us this long and carving itself into many of our childhoods, a scar we all wear with honor and love. Get the game, it's worth it... how do you not have it already?

9/10
This game was just as good as I remembered it being, While I do think Portal 2 is the better overall game, Portal 1's focus on making you feel so alone and uneasy was just beautifully done in this game, which is a theme that Portal 2 does use less of. The puzzles are pretty easy for me now,  as I have played soooo much Portal, and especially fan mods of Portal that heavily increase difficulty, that the current puzzles were obviously very easy for me and I breezed through them, but that is just something that happens when you replay portal games tbh.
Gameplay
Innovative, clean, and the best Puzzle Platformer out there. Nothing feels more satisfying then to finally solve a puzzle after analyzing the room for a bit. While it was rare for me to figure out what to do as they were very outlined on the solution, it was still amazing of a feeling to figure out the puzzle even after all these time. The game is pretty short, and while I did replay it so I was able to shave half of the usual time, I still think the game's pacing overall was very solid. My favorite is def act 3 of the game, as it just causes everything building up to finally pay off.

Story
While not as straight forward and told as in Portal 2, what Portal 1 does do beautifully is visual story telling (and GLaDOS taunting you the whole game), while also making you question if you are really alone. As you progress through the game you start to question "why are there cameras constantly watching my every movement?" or "why are there glass panels that seem like people should be watching me?", and lastly "who is this rat man?". While the story is still told to you via GLaDOS, the best part of the story is most defiantly what is around you and how you analyze each location.

Music
It's Portal Music, of course it's amazing. While there weren't as many memorable songs compared to it's sequel since most of the game is quiet, there were still a ton of songs that were just outright beautiful (or thrilling depending on which song you are talking about).

Characters
This game only really had 1 character, GLaDOS, and that was all the game really needed (unless you count Rat Man's ramblings). While the sequel introduced many more characters, having GLaDOS as this unknown entity, unsure what their motivations are, or if they even care for your safe keeping was amazing.

Conclusion
Portal 1 was, and still is, an amazing Puzzle Platformer game. While the game's replay value can be a bit hindered as you already know the puzzles, it is still a treat to figure out the easter eggs and little story pieces the game throws in each corner. I still do think Portal 2 is overall the better package, Portal 1 will still hold a place in my heart as the best one in terms of feeling alone, unease, and best of all, the feeling of being watched/ somebody should be there but isn't and my god I loved every second of that feeling.
9/10

receta de tarta de chocolate

Ingredientes para la base
125 g de manteca
250 g de harina 0000
20 g de cacao
125 g de azúcar
Pizca de sal
1 huevo
1 molde circular de 24 centímetros, enmantecado y enharinado
El relleno
200 g de chocolate amargo cobertura
350 cc de crema de leche
50 g de azúcar
3 yemas
Preparación
Paso 1

Cortar la manteca en cubos, debe estar fría.

Paso 2

En un bol, tamizar la harina y el cacao y mezclarlos. Sumar el azúcar y la sal. Comenzar a incorporar la manteca en cubos y con la mano, unirla a los ingredientes secos, hasta lograr una masa arenosa.

Paso 3

Agregar el huevo, integrar, pero sin amasar mucho, para que la masa no tome temperatura. Cubrir con film y guardar en la heladera 1 hora.

Paso 4

Retirar la masa de la heladera y estirar con palote, de un espesor de ½ centímetro. Disponer la masa sobre el molde y pincharla con un tenedor, para evitar que leude al ser horneada. Guardar nuevamente en la heladera media hora.

Paso 5

Cocinar la masa en horno precalentado 10 minutos, a 180°, para darle una precocción. Reservar.

Paso 6

El relleno: picar el chocolate en cubos y colocarlo en un bol resistente al calor. En una cacerolita, calentar la crema de leche sin que llegue a hervor, sumar el azúcar y revolver hasta disolverla. Verter la crema caliente sobre sobre el chocolate; mezclar hasta derretirlo completamente.

Paso 7

Dejar entibiar y sumar las yemas. Mezclar, hasta lograr una preparación homogénea.

Paso 8

El armado. Verter el relleno sobre la masa precocida y volver a cocinar en el horno de 20 a 25 minutos a 150° a 160° Retirar, dejar entibiar y servir tibia o fría.

This is definetely S-tier Valve game, in fact one of the most, if not the most innovative one, especially at the time it came out, but even nowadays the concept of having fun while you navigate with two different portals that are connected with real-time map coordinates is still pretty fresh and entertaining. Portal's plot is really simple, sometimes to the point of being completely useless, but the ubiquitous mystery of where we are and what exactly is this place kind of makes up for it. This type of games with undeveloped story need really fun mechanics and enjoyful gameplay to carry the experience and fortunately for Portal, that's what this game is all about. Graphics are nothing special, but level design is really amazing - every chamber and maintance area were created beautifully and specifically to fit into the gameplay with portal usage. The game is nearly perfect, the only issue I have and what I noticed some of the critics also pointed out already in 2007 is that it's too short when it comes to the storyline. Of course, there are a lot of bonus maps and challenges which btw take a lot of effort and time to complete, but they aren't as fun as playing the story mode for the first time. With that being said, Portal is amazing, but not perfect and that's why it's a 𝟵/𝟭𝟬. (oh yeah, jokes are pretty funny, but come on, it's not like I'm about to burst in laughter after AI voice makes a stupid remark or something, they are not that good, chill out)
